intro: I reserved the "Firefox" zeroid for you.

post.body: I created a site to test my experimental script of downloading big files (currently 5MB). Could anyone have a look and test it out? http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/
I added some videos and posters to my **ZeroBlog Lab** site for testing big file streaming.

Currently, ZeroNet saves all files into the `data` folder, which is why people don't like big sites. `:(`

If we can move the big file to a place rich in space while still keeping ZeroNet seeding it, we will be more pleased to stream big files from the ZeroNet. `:)` @nofish

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/
Firefox users can now play the video when it is still being downloaded.
The player will show up when the first 1/5 of the progress bar has been filled.

[1] Please click on the links labelled **Stream** if you would like to test this feature. I was not realized that the first two videos are not streaming friendly.

[2] Firefox is recommended :)

While I am optimizing the MP4 fragmenting program, I rearranged `ui.js` and published the rearranged version [on my site](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/big/js/ui.js). Hopefully people who would like to read my code can understand it more easily.

Big sites take so long to sign...

Perhaps I can:
- Use separate `content.json` files.
- Be patient.

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V
Now the big file streaming script is checking the hash of the big, reassembled file in a Web Worker.

I tested it against a 200MB file. When the hash of the big file was being checked, the web page still responded to scrolling and video seeking.

Though it is not necessary to check the hash of the reassembled file, I worked out a way to use Web Workers in ZeroNet's `iframe` without running into any cross origin errors.

If a cross origin error causes `new Worker("async-hash.js");` and `importScripts('asmcrypto.js');` to fail, putting the content of the script into a `blob:` URL can bypass this error.

Do pictures work?

No...... for security reasons.

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V

The MP4 multiplexer, written completely in JavaScript, is finally live on my website!

If you are using Firefox, you can **play any video on that page as you are buffering it**.

You can't believe the amount of code I wrote.

I am going to write some docs on my JavaScript projects, the file downloading script and the MP4 multiplexer. However, they do not have very beautiful **names**. Any suggestions on how they should be called?

    ZeroChunks     mp4fragment.js
    ZeroBytes      mp4mux.js
    ZeroBigFile    ZeroMux

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/big/docs/

It seems that the pages generated by MkDocs download a font from Google's server. I have blocked the referrer for better privacy.

    <meta name="referrer" content="no-referrer">

    <link href="font-awesome.css" rel="stylesheet" crossorigin="anonymous">
I cannot see some people's posts. Do I need to seed all ZeroMe hubs?
@nofish: As ZeroMe gets bigger, it may need a personal blacklist feature.

##How to block a person on ZeroMe
1. Find the public key of the person you want to block.
2. Find the folder named after that public key in the hub folder.
3. Go into that person's folder and look at `data.json`. Make sure that person is the right person you want to block.
4. Delete all his or her files, including `content.json`. Then immediately make a `content.json` **folder** at the same place to prevent that file from showing up again.
5. You cannot see that person's posts and comments anymore.
The [documentaion](/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/big/docs/) of ZeroMux is finished. Now the question remains: can you understand it?

Playing lossless (FLAC) music in browser.
What do you think?

comment.body: @Nofish: I agree. Using `_top` works best in most browsers.
You can label files as "optional files", so they do take space but do not count as site size.

@Sirenyc: There is an example on [ReadTheDocs](https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/site_development/content_json/#optional) and an example on my site: 
`"optional": "(big/files/.*dat)"`
It is a Regular Expression
You can use `"optional": "(big/files/.*jpg)"`

According to @nofish, big file support is planned. [Here](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/7#issuecomment-246185262) is the issue #7 on big file support. Here is the [pull request](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/pull/521) on big file support. These are all I know about big file support.
On the other hand, I want to keep file loading in browser, I don't want to do video conversion by hand, and I don't know how to modify the code of ZeroNet, so I made my own file loading script. My code is different and separate.
There is a like button, but I believe adding a "dislike" button is wasting data.
